item.title: Russia Bans Foul Language in Some Prisons; No Word on Enforcement
item.description: Detainees in pretrial detention centers will be forbidden to use slang known as “fenya,” but there was no immediate indication of how the authorities intended to enforce the rule.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inmates at a prison outside of Novgorod, south of St. Petersburg, in 2008. Under a new rule, detainees in pretrial detention centers will be banned from using the slang of the Russian prison system, known as “fenya.”

item.title: As Aid Reaches Syrians, U.N. Chief Says Withholding Food Is a War Crime
item.description: As aid convoys reached three besieged towns in Syria, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon called on all sides to lift sieges and protect civilians.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Residents of Madaya, Syria, waiting for an aid convoy on Thursday.

item.title: 5 Works From Gurlitt Collection Wrongfully Taken From Jews, Task Force Finds
item.description: The discovery of more than 1,200 pieces in a Munich apartment in 2012 stirred outrage, as did the idea that they had been kept secret for so long.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: The apartment building in Munich where Cornelius Gurlitt lived, shown in 2013.

item.title: 3 Found Guilty of Aiding $20 Million London Theft
item.description: The men were convicted of having helped a gang of four aging thieves who drilled into the side of a safe deposit building to steal a trove of gold, gems and jewelry.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: British Metropolitan Police Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Holes bored through the concrete wall of a basement vault at Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd. in London.

item.title: Missing a Road in Russia? This May Be Why
item.description: A prison official was charged with the theft of 30 miles of pavement in a thinly populated, heavily forested region of northern Russia.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: The Shah of Iran, the Islamic Revolution and the Mystery of the Missing Imam
item.description: A new book, “The Fall of Heaven,” offers clues on the 1978 disappearance of Moussa al-Sadr, a revered Iranian cleric in Lebanon who offered to help counter Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Imam Moussa al-Sadr, an Iranian-born cleric, in the 1970s. Mr. Sadr, who lived in Lebanon and became an ardent advocate of its impoverished Shiites, was last seen on Aug. 31, 1978, in Tripoli, Libya.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: India's Move Against the Poor
item.description: The Supreme Court upholds a discriminatory law that limits the political participation of the uneducated.
item.dc:creator: MUKUL KESAVAN

item.title: VW’s Chief Meets Head of E.P.A. to Discuss Pollution Problem
item.description: The visit by Matthias Müller was meant to help VW smooth relations with regulators in the United States.
item.dc:creator: JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:credit: Fabrizio Costantini for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matthias Müller, Volkswagen’s chief executive, was in Washington to discuss a solution to the company’s emissions problem.

item.title: Letter From Europe: In Britain, Major Parties Ensnared by Internal Strife
item.description: Since the May election, both the Labour Party, which was defeated, and the Conservative Party, which won, have been at war within themselves.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, left, leader of the Labour party, and his spokesman on economic issues, John McDonnell, at a party conference in Brighton, Britain, in September.

item.title: Deadliest Ebola Outbreak on Record Is Over, W.H.O. Says
item.description: The announcement came after a recent chain of cases in Liberia was snuffed out, ending an epidemic that killed more than 11,300 people, mostly in West Africa.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY, NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and CLAIR MacDOUGALL
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A doctor administered a blood test at the Logan Town clinic in Monrovia, Liberia, last year.

item.title: Jakarta Attack Kills 2, Raising Fears of Growing ISIS Reach
item.description: The two civilians dead after the explosions and gunfire were a Canadian and an Indonesian, senior officials reported, and five assailants were also killed.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Guards near the site of an explosion in Jakarta, Indonesia.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Secret Behind Italy’s Favorite New Film
item.description: The new film “Quo Vado?” is bigger than “Star Wars,” because it speaks to the country’s nostalgia for safe, secure careers.
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Jerusalem Journal: In Walled Old City, Evictions Seen as Stirring Up ‘Hornet’s Nest’
item.description: Palestinian residents of the Khaldiyya Ascent are facing eviction threats by Jewish organizations reclaiming properties they owned before Israel was established.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nazira Maswadi, left, with her daughter, Alia Maswadi, right, and two grandchildren at the home in Jerusalem’s Old City from which they face eviction.

item.title: 20 Nations’ Nuclear Facilities Said to Be Vulnerable to Cyberattack
item.description: Those countries, which have significant atomic stockpiles or nuclear power plants, do little to protect them from such intrusions, the Nuclear Threat Initiative says.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Living Under the Sword of ISIS in Syria
item.description: To the residents of Raqqa, the Islamic State is a brutal occupier that has brought nothing but misery.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MARWAN HISHAM

item.title: Italy Arrests Suspect in Death of American Woman
item.description: The police in Florence held a Senegalese man in connection with the killing of Ashley Ann Olsen, 35, of Florida.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:description: Italian forensic specialists outside the Florence apartment where the body of Ashley Ann Olsen, 35, was found on Saturday.

item.title: Jakarta Attack May Signal Revival of Bloody Campaign in Indonesia
item.description: Indonesian jihadists appear to have increasingly sought targets at home, stoking worries about violence that has plagued the country for the past decade and a half.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Bombings in 2002 on the Indonesian resort island of Bali killed more than 200 people, a majority of them foreigners.

item.title: In Syrian Town Cut Off From the World, Glimpses of Deprivation
item.description: Even now, after aid agencies negotiated to bring food and supplies to Madaya, there is little hope for change in a place trying to function while under siege.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Residents of the besieged town of Madaya, Syria, prepared to leave on Monday.

item.title: World Briefing: Honduras: 3 Americans Killed in Crash
item.description: Two students and a health care worker died Wednesday in a bus crash as they headed to an airport for a flight home after a volunteer mission.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Is Newest Frontier for a Daredevil Investor
item.description: James Passin of Firebird Management says he believes the neo-Stalinist country holds extensive oil reserves.
item.dc:creator: PENN BULLOCK
item.media:credit: Tom White for The New York Times
item.media:description: James Passin, a hedge fund manager at Firebird Management, at the Marina Bay Financial Center in Singapore.
